Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Interdisciplinary Frontiers of Designing Engineering Material Systems; College Station, Texas; 18-19 July 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The acceleration of materials discovery and development has long been recognized as important for solving technological challenges that impact our health, economic well-being, environment and national security. This is the central motivation for the materials Genome Initiative (MGI), which was announced by the White House in 2011, and ongoing efforts in Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME), which has been recognized by the National Academy of Science as being important for accelerated materials development. However, MGI and ICME research efforts tend to be only weakly-directed in the sense that they try to achieve materials with generally good properties (e.g., improved strength, lighter weight) or functionality (e.g., active materials) but often are not connected to a specific engineering design project. The concept of goal-directed design of materials and material systems holds great promise. Rather than relying on a separate process to deliver desirable materials or material systems, engineering designers can engage directly in the development of materials and material systems with the specific characteristics they need. This can lead to engineered systems with higher performance, lower cost, and that are more sustainable.

The goal of this workshop is to develop and articulate a vision for an interdisciplinary field of research focused the engineering design of materials and material systems. An interdisciplinary field is one that combines and adapts approaches from two or more fields so they are better suited for a problem of interest. This is in contrast to multidisciplinary research in which investigators pursue a problem using different disciplinary perspectives. To date, the most successful and impactful prior research on designing engineering material systems has been from an interdisciplinary perspective. An opportunity exists to accelerate research in this area by furthering the development of a coherent interdisciplinary community dedicated to understanding materials design problems. This workshop will bring together leading experts in materials and design research to identify ways to advance interdisciplinary research in this area. Participants will identify key knowledge areas for the interdisciplinary field, articulate critical open research questions and formulate steps to further advance the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this workshop was in the bringing together of over 50 faculty and government researchers that are leading experts in materials and design research to address the interdisciplinary frontiers of designing engineering material systems.  Through roundtable breakout sessions, these experts identified ways to advance interdisciplinary research in this area by addressing directly each objective of the workshop.  The specific objectives of the workshop were: 1) to identify open questions and research opportunities in the engineering design of materials and material systems; 2) to identify the types of evidence and/or evidence-gathering techniques that we would consider appropriate in research on methods for the engineering design of materials and material systems; 3) to identify concepts that are foundationally important to a new interdisciplinary field focused on research about the engineering design of materials and material systems. (Concepts that are neither solely about design nor solely about materials and that would be the basis of a shared understanding of the field.); 4) to articulate viable interdisciplinary strategies for investigating open research questions; 5) to articulate a set of guidelines/best practices by which researchers can evaluate proposed approaches for designing materials / material systems; 6) to identify professional development pathways (existing or needed) for the interdisciplinary field; and 7) to identify means by which we can develop and grow a community of researchers focusing on the topic of engineering design of materials and material systems.  Through the contributions of the attending experts, new insights into the scope of research challenges associated with the design of engineering material systems were generated.  Further, through the combination of design and materials researchers at the workshop, the identification of new directions and challenges was achieved that neither community was likely to have achieved in isolation.  These insights, directions, and challenges will be disseminated through a review paper that is in preparation and will be submitted to the ASME Journal of Mechanical Design Special Issue dedicated to the Design of Engineered Materials and Structures, which was inspired in part by this workshop.

From the perspective of broader impacts, the workshop has resulted in the definition of a new interdisciplinary field of research, as evidenced by the aforementioned special issue of the ASME Journal of Mechanical Design.  It is expected that the eventual societal impact of this field will be immense.  By tailoring the design of a material or system of materials to a particular design scenario, engineers can achieve greater levels of performance and economy simultaneously. Moreover, this area research potentially can unlock solutions that combine high performance and sustainability characteristics. This win-win situation is not reachable by either the materials or design communities alone and this workshop brought together the leaders in these fields and started a critical conversation regarding how to proceed and define the field, its opportunities, and its challenges.

Educational broader impacts as they apply to the participants were also generated. The workshop was designed with deliberate intentionality to orchestrate an event that would strategically and seamlessly bring together diverse groups in order to form an interdisciplinary field of research focused on combining and adapting approaches across disciplines. Workshop participants experienced firsthand the process of generating cross-disciplinary collaborations with new interdisciplinary foci. The researchers’ active participation in this unique workshop afforded them with the tools and resources necessary to help disseminate both the workshop process and the workshop’s findings, as well as furthering the development of new research communities. The ultimate goal is that the newly forged interdisciplinary relationships catalyze the creation of new courses, experiences, and potentially programs within and across institutions spanning the nation.
